page.title: 02Pembrokeshire Houses.
page.content: On the 23rd May, Helen, Annie and I, Anne Thomas went towards Templeton past Stoney Park and Tregellet where we saw two small bridges. There we met Mr. Noon. He said he really came from Hill Town near Derby. He worked in a factory making parachutes from cellulose. He said that if the parachute did not open they called it candling. Mr. Noon has lived in Wales for sixteen years. He lives in an old fashioned Pembrokeshire house. It has two rooms and a shed built on. There is a big chimney in which people can sit by the open fire. There is an upstairs to one end of the house. There are lots of coniferous trees in this area. We saw the two bridges. One is a "listed" pack horse bridge. It is three feet wide. The modern bridge can hold a sixteen ton milk lorry because we saw one on it.
